coredata.dc:title: Stable lithium metal anode achieved by shortening diffusion path on solid electrolyte interface derived from Cu2O lithiophilic layer
coredata.dc:creator: Cai, Yifei
Qin, Bin
Li, Chun
Si, Xiaoqing
Cao, Jian
Zheng, Xiaohang
Qi, Junlei
coredata.dc:description: The stable operation of lithium metal batteries is crucial for high energy density requirements, but it is plagued by Li dendrite growth and unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI). Lithiophilic transition metal oxides (TMOs) have been studied extensively on Cu current collectors to stabilize lithium metal anodes by decreasing the Li nucleation overpotential, yet less is known about the SEI derived from the lithiation reaction of TMOs. Here we report a novel approach to regulate the SEI interface precisely, especially to construct a nanoscale inorganic-dominated SEI with shortened diffusion path by controlling the oxidization state of Cu2O film on Cu current collector. The highly stable cyclic performance is achieved by generating the thin SEI that contains dense inorganic inner layer and organic layer. Consequently, the lithium metal anode based on Cu2O/Cu current collector exhibits low and stable polarization voltage for an ultralong life-span (∼22.5 mV at 1 mA cm−2 for 3000 h). This work elucidates the relationship between lithiation reaction of oxides modified layer and derived SEI, guiding for constructing stable lithium metal batteries.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Schematic of the SEI generation and relevant potential profiles. (a) schematic of natural SEI and derived SEI generation and relevant Li plating behavior. (b) the electric potential profile across the half-cell during Li plating process. (c) Schematic of uneven Li deposition induced by inhomogeneous nucleation of n-SEI and polarization effect of the thick d-SEI. (d) The typical potential curve at the first discharge process. (e) Potential curves for the 1-4th plating/stripping process. Cycling condition: 1 mA cm−2 for fixed 1 mAh cm−2 capacity.
SEM images of the prepared Cu foam/Cu2O current collectors with different oxidization times. (a-d) surface morphology of O-1, 3, 10 and 30. (e-h) Side views SEM images of O-1, 3, 10 and 30.

TEM images of the prepared Cu2O film with different reaction times. (a-c) TEM images and SAED pattern of O-1. Inset is the theoretical diffraction patterns of cubic Cu2O in (001) zone axis. TEM images and SAED pattern of (d-f) O-3, (g-i) O-10, and (j-l) O-30.

Compositional and electrochemical analysis of Cu2O modified Cu foam and derived anode. (a) XRD patterns, (b) Raman spectra of the as-obtained Cu2O modified Cu foam. Raman spectrum of O-3 sample (c) discharged to 0.01 V and (d) plating 1mAh cm-2 Li. (e) Discharge potential profiles and (f) CV curves of Cu foam and Cu2O modified Cu foam.

Electrochemical measurement of lithium metal anode based on Cu2O modified Cu foam. (a) CE of Li|Cu half-cells assembled with O-1, O-3, O-10, and O-30 measured at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2. (b-e) Voltage profiles of Li plating/stripping processes on Li|Cu half-cells assembled with O-1, O-3, O-10, and O-30 during 2–10 cycles. (f) Voltage profile comparison of Li|Cu half-cells assembled with O-1, O-3, O-10, and O-30 at the 10th cycle. (g) Rate performance of the symmetric cells assembled with O-3 and O-30 at different current densities of 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 5.0, 8.85 mA cm−2 with a fixed capacity of 1.0 mAh cm−2. (h) Nyquist plots of the impedance spectra of Li|Li symmetric cells assembled with O-3 and O-30.

XPS spectra of d-SEI formed on anode based on O-3 with depth profiling. High-resolution XPS spectra of (a) Li 1 s, (b) C 1 s, (c) O 1 s, (d) F 1 s, (e) S 2p, and (f) Cu 2p. The etching time is 0, 1, 2, 3, 4 min, respectively.

SEM images of Cu foam and O-3 with different Li stored states. (a) Cu foam plated with 1 mAh cm-2 Li. (b) O-3 discharge to 0.01 V. (c) O-3 plated with 1 mAh cm-2 Li. (d) O-3 plated with 2 mAh cm-2 Li. (e) O-3 plated with 10 mAh cm-2 Li. (f) O-3@10 mAh cm-2 Li anode after stripping. The insets in Fig. 7 b-f are the corresponding optical images of the sample.

head.ce:title: Stable lithium metal anode achieved by shortening diffusion path on solid electrolyte interface derived from Cu2O lithiophilic layer

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: State Key Laboratory of Advanced Welding and Joining, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, PR China

sa:affiliation.sa:organization: State Key Laboratory of Advanced Welding and Joining

ce:affiliation.ce:source-text: State Key Laboratory of Advanced Welding and Joining, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150001, PR China

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The stable operation of lithium metal batteries is crucial for high energy density requirements, but it is plagued by Li dendrite growth and unstable solid electrolyte interphase (SEI). Lithiophilic transition metal oxides (TMOs) have been studied extensively on Cu current collectors to stabilize lithium metal anodes by decreasing the Li nucleation overpotential, yet less is known about the SEI derived from the lithiation reaction of TMOs. Here we report a novel approach to regulate the SEI interface precisely, especially to construct a nanoscale inorganic-dominated SEI with shortened diffusion path by controlling the oxidization state of Cu2O film on Cu current collector. The highly stable cyclic performance is achieved by generating the thin SEI that contains dense inorganic inner layer and organic layer. Consequently, the lithium metal anode based on Cu2O/Cu current collector exhibits low and stable polarization voltage for an ultralong life-span (∼22.5 mV at 1 mA cm−2 for 3000 h). This work elucidates the relationship between lithiation reaction of oxides modified layer and derived SEI, guiding for constructing stable lithium metal batteries.

ce:section.ce:para: The urgent requirement for high energy density energy storage system gives rise to the reviving of interest of lithium (Li) metal anode due to the high theoretical capacity (3860 mAh g−1) and low redox potential [1-3]. Yet the issue of morphology/structure instability of Li plating/stripping prevented reliable cycling performance, which arises from Li dendrite growth, poor coulombic efficiency and drastic volume change [4-6]. Recently, 3D current collector has been used to achieve uniform Li deposition by reducing local current density and dispersing Li+ flux, thus the formation of Li dendrite can be delayed [7-9]. Among different non-Li metal substrates, copper (Cu) current collector is used for Li metal anode due to the excellent conductivity and chemical inertia. But the distinctive surface energy and lattice structure with Li brings about large nucleation barriers, which could lead to a non-conformal deposition morphology [10,11]. In order to reduce the nucleation barrier, transition metal oxides (TMOs) were used as lithiophilic modification layers to induce uniform Li metal nucleation [12-14].

Although the reduced nucleation barrier can be obtained by the TMOs lithiophilic layer, however, the vigorous side reaction between Li metal and electrolyte can still hamper the reversibility of interfacial Li deposition/stripping process [15-18]. A natural solid electrolyte interphase (n-SEI) formed on Li metal surfaces is too fragile to passivate Li anode [19-21]. The inner stress caused by volumetric change can lead to repeated breakdown/repair of n-SEI, result in dendrite growth and cell failure [22,23]. In contrast, artificial solid-electrolyte interphase (a-SEI) with a better passivation function was proposed to terminate the reaction between Li metal and electrolyte [15,24-26]. Besides, it is widely believed that a-SEI directed prepared on Li metal surface plays a crucial regulation role for Li plating/stripping process [27,28]. However, for TMOs modified current collectors, the derived SEI (d-SEI) on current collector has, so far, received minor attention, yet it is an important aspect for the present research [29,30].

The enhanced lithiophilic features by TMOs was originated by the conversion reaction that can be expressed as the equation [31-33]:
(1)

In the case of lithiation reaction of copper oxide, the product is comprised of intimate mixing of Li2O matrix embedding metal Cu nanocrystalline [34]. As a typical SEI component, Li2O exhibits ionic conductivity and electrical insulation properties [35,36]. And metal Cu nanocrystalline derived from lithiation reaction is most likely isolated [37]. Therefore, it can speculate that the Li2O/Cu interlayer can act as a SEI layer to induce Li+ deposit under the d-SEI, rather than deposit above the initial TMO layer due to the lack of a continuous electron conductive path [38]. More importantly, sluggish ionic diffusion on d-SEI can leads to an obvious polarization effect due to the low ionic conductivity to Li2O [35,39]. Therefore, the fragility of the Li+ transport pathway through the d-SEI is the critical barrier to enable reversible Li metal deposition. In the case of the TMO modified Cu current collector, the Li2O amounts on d-SEI are closely associated with the oxidization state (oxygen content) of initial oxide layer. Hence, optimizing the oxidization state of the TMO modified layer on Cu current collectors is a critical aspect to regulate the characteristic of the d-SEI and its polarization effects. Besides, Li et al. demonstrates the suppression function of TMO lithiophilic layer to electrolyte decomposition [30], but the components of the d-SEI are still unclear. A clear scenario of the effect of TMO-derived SEI on Li plating/stripping process is urgently needed.

Herein, Cu2O modified Cu foam current collector was prepared by oxygen plasma treatment, and the oxidation state of the Cu2O modified layer was adjusted continuously by changing reaction time. The obtained Cu2O film serves as a paradigm to investigate the d-SEI at Cu foam and related polarization effect in lithium metal anode. The results show that the oxidation state of the TMO layer has a non-monotonic correlation with the polarization effect of the lithium anode. The lithium metal anode based on optimized Cu2O layer exhibits the lowest resistance and polarization effect, which facilitated reversibility of Li plating/stripping process. The prepared lithium metal anode delivers a low and stable polarization voltage during the long-term cyclic process (∼22.5 mV at 1 mA cm−2 for 3000 h).

We obtained the Cu2O modified Cu foam by a facile one-step oxygen plasma treatment. Cu2O’s oxidation state was adjusted by varying reaction times, and the samples obtained in 1, 3, 10, 30 min were designated as O-1, O-3, O-10, and O-30, respectively. The optical images of pristine Cu foam and the four samples are given in Figure S1. As the reaction times increasing, the color of Cu/Cu2O samples changed from light yellow to brownish. This implies the Cu2O film has the tendency of thickening. The schematic of generation of n-SEI on untreated Cu foam and d-SEI on oxidized Cu foam is given in Fig. 1 a. Compared with the disordered, fragile n-SEI, the Cu2O could turns into a uniform and robust d-SEI that possess protective function due to the inorganic conversion products. The lithium metal anode on Cu current collector is generally prepared by electrodepositing metal lithium on a half-cell consisting of two electrodes (pristine current collectors and lithium foil). Fig. 1b-c shows the electric potential profile across the Cu/Cu2O|Li foil half-cell in the initial open-circuit state and Li plating state [40]. The electric potential ( ϕ ) is inversely proportional to the electrochemical potential of the electron (
μ ∼
e
-
) according to the following equation [41]:
(2)
μ ∼

μ

where
μ

is the chemical potential of electron in the system (approximately equal to Fermi energy). The model is established on following assumptions and theories. (1) The metal part is represented with an equipotential body due to their high electric conductivity and free electron concentration. In other words, we assume that net charge accumulation at the metal can be ignored. Thus, the potential in metal was plotted as a horizontal line. (2) Space charge effects in the boundary of SEI and electrolyte could lead to potential bending according to the sign of the effective charge. (3) The potential mutation between electrode/electrolyte can be explained by the existence of “potential of zero charge”.

As the galvanostatic discharge progressed, Cu2O layer can be converted to a “derived” SEI, then Li+ diffused through the SEI and is deposited. When lithium metal was plated, the half-cell exhibits a negative response voltage (overpotential, around a few dozen millivolts). The total overpotential can be divided into two parts which including mass-transfer and electro-reaction. In the stable plating stage that after Li nucleation, the potential profile in d-SEI and electrolyte was plotted by a sloping line due to the constant inner electric field is built. Given the Li+ adsorption and reduction has relatively faster kinetics than the mass-transfer process in the solid phase, the polarization voltage (Δφ) on SEI can affect Li plating/stripping process more significantly. The value of Δφ can be reduced by shortening diffusion length of Li+ in d-SEI, which requires minimizing the electrolyte decomposition and the amounts of Cu2O conversion reaction. Therefore, we predicted there should be an optimized oxidization state for the oxide film to obtain the minimum Δφ.

The typical first discharge curve of Cu/Cu2O electrode (O-3) is given in Fig. 1d. The curve can be divided into three parts. The first part with a blue mark exhibits a voltage plateau at ∼ 1.2 V and a sloping line from 1.2 V to 0 V, ascribing to lithiation of Cu2O and electrolyte reduction decomposition. The second part with a red mark exhibits a sharp voltage dip, which can be attributed to metal Li nucleation. The third part with purple marker exhibits a stable long voltage plateau corresponds to metal Li deposition. Note that the voltage plateau at ∼ 1.25 V and the slopping line from 1.2 to 0 V disappeared after the first discharge process. This implies that the lithiation of Cu2O is irreversible, and the electrolyte reduction almost terminated during subsequent cycles. To verify this inference, Fig. 1e gives the voltage curves during 1-4th plating/stripping cycles. Only the first discharge processes an obvious lithiophilic capacity in the positive voltage range (∼0.6 mAh cm−2), while the 2-4th discharge processes all deliver a tiny lithiophilic capacity (∼0.05 mAh cm−2). Besides, two critical characteristics of overpotential can be identified in Fig. 1e. One is the Li nucleation overpotential (ηn), which is the difference between the voltage dip and the plateau [42]. Another is mass-transfer related overpotential, denoted as “Li deposition polarization voltage” (ηp) here, which is the difference voltage plateau and equilibrium potential of the Li/Li+. There are some differences in overpotential in the first discharge process and subsequent discharge process. The ηn shows a gradually decreasing trend during the 1–4 cycles. (∼26 mV for 1st and ∼ 13 mV for 4th discharge process) In comparison, the ηp for 1–4 cycles is almost the same (-20.8 mV for 1st and ∼ 18.6 mV for 2-4th discharge process). The decrease of μn implies metal Li in some nucleation sites cannot be completely stripped when first charged to 1 V and it reduces the nucleation energy required for the next lithium plating, which is consistent with the gradual increasing trend of Coulombic efficiency (CE) in the early cycles. (Figure S2) The steady μp suggested that the d-SEI delivers superior electrochemical stability, and the conversion from Cu2O to Li2O is almost irreversible.

To investigate the morphology of the prepared Cu/Cu2O electrode and the thickness of the oxide layer, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) SEM characterization was conducted. The plane views of O-1, 3, 10, 30 are given in Fig. 2 a-d. O-1, O-3 and O-10 samples exhibit similar rough surfaces, while numerous nanoparticles with irregular edges are raised on the surface. The nanoparticles of O-1 exhibit a relatively small average size of ∼68 nm, while that of O-3 and O-10 delivers a larger average size of around 90 nm. (Figure S3) When the reaction time is further prolonged to 30 min, the nanoparticles of O-30 are gradually “melt” and bond with adjacent particles, results in an irregular morphology. The typical cross-section SEM images of O-1, 3, 10 and O-30 are shown in Fig. 2e-h. The results show the thickness are ∼44, ∼80, ∼120 and ∼180 nm, respectively, indicating the thickening of the oxide film with prolong reaction time. The morphology characterization result indicates that the oxide film can be in-situ synthesized on pristine Cu foam skeleton by oxygen plasma treatment, and the thickness of the oxide layer can be simply tuned in nanoscale by changing reaction time.

The microstructure of the prepared oxide film was characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Fig. 3 shows TEM images of O-1,3 and 30. In Fig. 3a-b, the O-1 sample shows an ultrathin film structure with a relatively smooth surface and miscellaneous ultrafine particles. Besides, the oxide film in O-1 possesses slight local holes, suggesting an incomplete coverage. The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns of the film show an approximate single-crystal feature, which agrees with the theoretical patterns for the cubic Cu2O (001) zone axis. With reaction time prolong, the darker contrast in Fig. 3d indicated an enlarged film thickness. And the smooth surface becomes rougher with numerous pits. The rough surface provides an enlarged surface area, which is beneficial for reducing local current density and dispersing Li+ flux. Besides, the SAED pattern in Fig. 3f shows an approximated multi-crystal feature, and the calculated d-spacing for the (h k l) planes is also corresponds to theoretical values of cubic Cu2O. The result implies the O-3 sample has not yet undergone a phase transition, maintains a pure phase component. The perpendicular interplanar spacings of 0.302 nm in a high-resolution TEM image of O-3 (Figure S4) confirmed the cubic Cu2O phase. The TEM images of O-10 and O-30 are given in Fig. 3g-l. The contrast of the film becomes darker, indicates that the thickness was further increased. Meanwhile more obvious pits structure was formed. Fig. 3i and 3l shows a complex diffraction pattern. Except for the similar diffraction rings of Cu2O, some additional spots with weak brightness appeared on SAED pattern of O-10, and the number of these extra diffraction spots becomes greater on that of O-30. The d-spacing from these additional spots corresponds well to that of CuO. The result suggests partial phase transition occurred when excessively prolonging the oxidization time. Besides, in order to verify the microstructure of Li2O/Cu interlayer derived from Cu2O film, HRTEM characterization was performed to examine the microstructure of the lithiation product. And Figure S4 shows that the isolated Cu nanocrystalline is tightly embedded in the amorphous Li2O matrix. Therefore, it can speculate that be the electro-plated Li most likely deposited under the Li2O/Cu interfacial layer due to the lack of a continuous electron conductive path [38].

X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterizations were conducted to probe the phase component of the prepared oxide film. The XRD patterns of O-1, 3, 10 and, 30 are given in Fig. 4 a. The three peaks at 43.3°, 50.4°, and 74.1° appeared in all the patterns are indexed to metal Cu (111), (200), and (220) standard diffraction peaks, respectively. Except for metal Cu peaks, two small peaks at 31° and 42° are observed on the XRD pattern of O-1, which can be ascribed to cuprite Cu2O phase (111) and (220) standard diffraction peak (JCPDS 05–0667). With reaction time prolonged, the intensity of the Cu2O (111) peak gradually strengthened. Noteworthy that no diffraction peak of CuO was observed even in the XRD pattern of O-30. The result implies that the CuO content is too low to detect in XRD measurement. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was conducted to investigate the surface chemical states of O-3 and O-30. (Figure S5) Although both Cu1+ and Cu2+ components were observed, O-3 shows minor Cu2+ features, while O-30 shows a much higher part of Cu2+ bonds. Moreover, the O1s spectrum of O-30 shows higher Cu–O content than that of the O-1 sample. The oxidation state of O-1, 3, 10, 30 was further studied by Raman spectroscopy. Fig. 4b shows that all these four sample exhibits similar Raman peaks at ∼ 154 cm−1, ∼220 cm−1 and ∼ 640 cm−1. These three Raman peaks can be attributed to activated
Γ
15
( 1 )
,
2
Γ
12
-
and
Γ
15
( 2 )
phonon vibration frequency of Cu2O [43]. In contrast, the Raman peak at ∼ 298 cm−1 can be assign with Ag vibration modes of CuO [44]. The gradually enhanced intensity of the Ag peak from O-3 to O-30 confirmed the increased oxidation valence of the copper oxide film. The negative shift of
Γ
15
( 2 )
peak of Cu2O from O-3 to O-30 may cause by the appearance of 632 cm−1 characterized peak of CuO, which is also consistent with the increased oxidation state of the oxide film. The O-3 sample discharged to 0.01 V, and plated with 1 mAh cm-2 Li was further characterized by Raman scattering spectrum. In Fig. 4c, the peaks at 533.6 cm−1 and 1089.6 cm−1 can ascribe to Li2O and Li2CO3, respectively [45,46]. The peak at 410 cm−1 may attribute to interface between Li2O and nano Cu. The remaining peak of Cu2O may cause by insufficient transformation reaction. The formation of Li2CO3 indicated that electrolyte is involved in the formation of d-SEI. After plating 1 mAh cm-2 Li, the Raman spectrum in Fig. 4d only shows two board peaks at 537.3 and 874.4 cm−1, which correspond to organic/amorphous SEI component (such as lithium alkyl carbonate) on the electrode surface [47]. The result demonstrates that the d-SEI is composed of mixed products of conversion reaction of oxide and electrolyte decomposition. The former mainly generates Li2O and nano Cu, while the latter produces Li2CO3 and organic products. The typical galvanostatic charge–discharge (GCD) profiles of Cu foam and O-1, 3, 10, 30 are given in Fig. 4e. All samples had similar high initial open-circuit voltages (OCP). However, the lithiation capacities of these samples are quite different. The lithiation capacity shows a significant correlation with the oxygen plasma treatment time, which means that the lithiation capacity is dependent on the oxidation state of the oxide film. The lithiation capacity calculated from the galvanostatic discharge curves of Cu foam, O-1, 3, 10, 30 is 0.017, 0.329, 0.608, 1.232 and 1.622 mAh cm−2, respectively. The linear scan voltammetry measurement for Cu foam and O-1, 3, 10, 30 in Fig. 4f. All the copper oxide modified sample exhibits obvious reduction peak at ∼ 1 V, while Cu foam only delivers tiny current response in the positive potential region. Moreover, the capacity based on the integrated area of reduction peak (from 0 to 1.5 V) is highly correlated with the oxidation state of the oxide film. Based on GCD and LSV results, it can be concluded that the higher the oxygen content in the oxide layer, the more lithium ions are consumed through the transformation reaction during the first discharge process, so the greater the amount of d-SEI can be generated. The copper oxide film is eventually converted to Li2O, which is a crucial component of d-SEI. An appropriate amount of Li2O can passivate the lithium metal and inhibit the continuous decomposition of the electrolyte, while a large amount of Li2O can result in excessively thick d-SEI. The continued electrolyte decomposition and overly thick d-SEI can lead to considerable interfacial impedance and polarization effects.

The cyclic Li plating/stripping measurement was performed on Li|Cu half-cells assembled with O-1, 3, 10, 30. The charge–discharge depth is 1 mAh cm−2 in 1 mA cm−2. The Coulombic efficiencies (CE) were shown in Fig. 5 a. The CE of all half-cells gradually increased to ∼ 98% and stabilized during the first 5–10 cycles. The result implies that a stable d-SEI is formed after the first 5–10 plating/stripping cycles. Besides, there is a non-monotonic relationship between the stability of CE and the oxidation state during the whole plating/stripping cycle. At the 200th cycle, the CE of the O-1 half-cell with the weakest oxidation state had decayed to less than 90%. In contrast, the O-3 half-cell exhibits the best stability, which maintains a stable CE at ∼ 97.7% after 250 cycles. With further strengthening oxidation state, O-10 and O-30 half-cell delivers degenerate cyclic stability, which shows decreased CE at ∼ 90% after 250 cycles and 230 cycles. More importantly, the polarization voltage of these four samples can be reflected in voltage profiles. The voltage profiles at 2–10 cycles of O-1, 3, 10, 30 half-cells are given in Fig. 5b-e. The polarization voltage of all the samples decreased gradually and tended to be stable during the 10th plating/stripping process. The total polarization voltage of O-1, 3, 10, 30 half-cells at the 10th plating/stripping process were 34.1, 28.2, 38.7 and 49.6 mV, respectively. The trend of polarization voltage is consistent with the oxidation state of the oxide film. Encouraged by the intriguing electrochemical performances of Li|Cu half-cells, symmetric cells based on O-3 and O-30 with pre-deposited 10 mAh cm-2 Li were assembled. As shown in Fig. 5f, the long-term cyclic stability measurement was tested at 1 mA cm−2 with a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 for each cycle. An ultra-long and stable polarization voltage can be obtained on O-3 symmetric cells for 3000 h, while the polarization voltage of O-30 symmetric cells become unstable after 2800 h.(Magnified details is given in Figure S7) The extraordinary long-term cycling stability is superior to most state-of-the-art TMOs interfacial layer-based Li metal anodes reported before. (Table S1) Besides, the symmetric cell assembled with O-3 exhibits lower polarization voltage than that of O-30 in early cycles, implies the smaller impedance of O-3. To verify the polarization voltage difference, the rate performance of these two symmetrical cells was further examined. The rate measurement was conducted with difference current densities of 0.2, 0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 5.0, 8.85 mA cm−2 and back to 0.2 mA cm−2. As shown in Fig. 5g, the polarization voltage difference between O-3 and O-30 symmetric cell becomes increasingly noticeable as current density rises. Even when the current density reaches 8.85 mA cm−2, the polarization voltage of O-3 symmetric cell is only ∼ 50 mV, while that of O-30 symmetric cell can be over 80 mV. The resistance regarding the SEI derived from O-3 and O-30 was obtained using Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). Unsurprisingly, the Nyquist plot in Fig. 5h shows that the symmetric cell assembled with O-3 exhibits a smaller semi-circle in high frequency region, which implies that the cell possesses smaller SEI resistance. Besides, the impedance of the Li|Cu half-cell based on O-3 was also measured. It is found that the impedance decreases in early cycles (Figure S8), which can ascribe to Li “surface reorganization” and SEI “consolidation”[48].

In-depth XPS spectra of the lithium anode based on O-3 were shown in Fig. 6 to provide insight into the component features of d-SEI produced from Cu2O modified layer in LiTFSI electrolyte. The surface and interior components of d-SEI are significantly different. Fig. 6a provides the Li 1 s in-depth XPS spectra. Before and after Ar+ spur, the peak of Li-carbonate at 55.2 eV nearly did not change, while the peak corresponding Li2O (54.0 eV) and LiF (55.7 eV) mainly appeared in the interior part of d-SEI. Besides, the metal Li (52.4 eV) absence indicated that d-SEI possesses a compact structure and can prevent “leakage current”. The C1s, O1s and F1s spectra in Fig. 6b-d show that the d-SEI layer is consists of hierarchical organic–inorganic composition, where alkyl carbonate (290 eV), C-O (286.8 eV) and C–C (284.8 eV) species are mainly distributed on the outer surface. In comparison, Li2CO3 (289.8 eV for C1s, 531.5 eV for O1s) permeated the inner layer of d-SEI [49]. Other inorganic components such as Li2O (528.2 eV for O1s) and LiF (684.5 eV for F1s) are also located in the inner part of d-SEI. The presence of CF3 (688.4 eV for F1s) can ascribe to TFSI anion. The S 2p spectra in Fig. 6e shows tiny sulphone (169.2 eV) and sulfate (170.7 eV) based organic-components are located in the outer layer. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 6f, no Cu 2p signal was found in the outer surface, whereas metal Cu (∼933 eV) peaks can be observed in the inner layer. The existence of metal Cu is ascribed to conversion reaction products of Cu2O film. A schematic diagram of d-SEI is given in Figure S9. The atomic percentages of specific components (normalized by LiF, Li2O and Cu) along with the depth is given in Figure S10. The proportion of Li2O and metal Cu both gradually promoted with depth increasing. Therefore, it can be inferred that the inner d-SEI is a dense inorganic layer which is Cu2O conversion-dominated, whereas the outside layer is electrolyte reduction-dominated. Therefore, the inner inorganic layer of SEI can be regulated by adjusting the oxidation state of initial Cu2O film, thus facilitating the ionic diffusion and improving structural stability of SEI.

In order to investigate the regulation effect of SEI derived from Cu2O film for metal Li plating/stripping process, the Li|Cu half-cells assembled with Cu foam and O-3 in different Li stored states was dissembled, and the morphologies were characterized by SEM. As shown in Fig. 7 a, the isolated Li spheres and dendrites in Cu foam indicate uneven nucleation and deposition behavior. In contrast, the d-SEI shows a smooth surface in Fig. 7b when O-3 was discharged to 0.01 V, implies an even d-SEI formation. Moreover, the O-3 current collector exhibits a high tolerance on overcharge. Fig. 7c-e shows the uniform and compact morphologies in different Li amounts (1, 2, and 10 mAh cm−2). Besides, after stripping the pre-stored metal Li, the O-3 current collector still shows a relative plain surface (Fig. 7f), indicates a stable stripping behavior of the lithium metal anode. The insets in Fig. 7b-f are optical images of the corresponding samples, which all show relatively uniform surface. Besides, the O-3@Li anode was paired with LiFePO4 cathode. In Figure S11, the obtained full cell exhibits low voltage hysteresis (0.16 V at 0.5 C) and superior cyclic performance (138 mAh g−1 after 320 cycles at 0.5 C). Furthermore, the rate performance of LFP|O-3@Li battery was measured and the results are given in Figure S12. The specific capacity of the full cell achieves 160, 148, 137, 125, 116 mAh g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 3 C, respectively. Even at the high rate of 3 C, the voltage hysteresis does not exceed 0.5 V. The excellent specific capacity, small polarization voltage, and outstanding rater performance of the full cell further demonstrated the merits of the d-SEI formed from Cu2O film with optimized oxidation states.

In summary, we have demonstrated a new strategy to achieve a stable Li metal anode based on an oxide modified copper current collector. In this strategy, the oxidization state of the copper oxide film was rationally regulated by oxygen plasma treatment, and the derived SEI was anchored on the Cu foam during the first discharge process. The uniform Cu2O film with optimized oxidation state contributed to the formation of the dense inorganic layer in SEI that with high ionic conductivity and mechanical strength, which favors for homogenous Li plating and stripping. Accordingly, the lithium metal anode based on optimized Cu2O film exhibits an ultra-stable reversible Li plating/stripping behavior for 3000 h with a tiny polarization voltage of ∼ 22.5 mV. This work broadens the understanding and strategies for constructing artificial SEI through the conversion reaction of lithiophilic oxides on Cu current collectors.
